body:
Conservative Christianity has done nothing at all in conserving anything from the Early Church. In fact, these "conservative" Christians have adopted very modern, heretical ideas.

1. Destructive End times
2. Eternal Torment in Hell
3. Just Wars for country, violence can save for the greater good
4. God Killed Jesus for you (Penal Substitution Theory)
5. Pledging Allegiance to your empire

In contrast true conservative Christianity is

1. Revelation has already happened,   Christians understood that Jesus achieved total victory on the cross and so the world would continue to get better as his Kingdom expanded and overtook the earth

2. The Church has always had three different views on hell: Universal Reconciliation, Annihilationism/Conditional Immortality, and Eternal Conscious Torment. We know that there were six theological schools operating in the first five or six centuries of Christianity in the cities of Alexandria, Antioch, Caesarea, Edessa, Ephesus, and Rome. Four of these schools taught Universal Reconciliation, one school taught Annilhilationism, and one taught Eternal Torment. So for around 500 years after the time of Christ, the majority view was Universal Reconciliation.   The one school that taught Eternal Torment was in Rome so that belief rose to dominance once the Emperor adopted the religion.  The Catholic Church used the fear of hell to motivate its parishioners for 1,500 years and so it is no wonder it is the major view today.

3. Christ was Pacifist and taught non-violence and commanded that you love your enemies.  In the early Church, Those who were in the military were not allowed to be baptized unless they abandoned their positions. It wasn’t even permitted for a Christian to wear any jewelry that had symbols of weapons on them.

4. This Idea was popularized by the Reformation especially John Calvin.  The Gospel according to Jesus was that the Kingdom of God had arrived. Jesus talked about this more than anything else, and the Kingdom is always how the Gospel is described in Scripture.

5. Jesus taught to be a citizen of the Kingdom of God.  Empires of the world are anything but.

Our "conservative" Christian friends have been led astray, and I hope that in time, they will come to correct their path.

In fact, God's plan would have been Jesus be King right then and there, where He would rule us as we expanded His Kingdom... if only we had accepted Him then... but we did not.  Jesus suffered because of our sin, we mounted Him on the cross, we tried to kill Him, not God.

body:
I do not believe that has biblical merit.

Nowhere in Scripture does it say that God killed Jesus. Jesus knew who would kill him and it wasn’t God (Matthew 21:33-46, Luke 11:47-51).

The early church says as much as well:

This man… you put him to death by nailing him to the cross. But God raised him from the dead…(Acts 2:23-24) You killed the author of life, but God raised him from the dead. (Acts 3:15) Jesus Christ of Nazareth, whom you crucified but whom God raised from the dead… (Acts 4:10) The God of our ancestors raised Jesus from the dead—whom you killed by hanging him on a cross. (Acts 5:30) Your ancestors even killed those who predicted the coming of the Righteous One. And now you have betrayed and murdered him. (Acts 7:52)

God's Justice is restorative, not retributive.

It wasn’t even permitted for a Christian to wear any jewelry that had symbols of weapons on them.

  4. This Idea was popularized by the Reformation especially John Calvin. The Gospel according to Jesus was that the Kingdom of God had arrived. Jesus talked about this more than anything else, and the Kingdom is always how the Gospel is described in Scripture.

  5. Jesus taught to be a citizen of the Kingdom of God. Empires of the world are anything but.

Our "conservative" Christian friends have been led astray, and I hope that in time, they will come to correct their path.
